Artemis @artemis
home original

I really don't like the word "crime" anymore.

It means "something that is against the law", so without specific context of what laws we're talking about, it's meaningless, & worse than that makes it sound like the reason something is wrong to do is that it's illegal.

It's at least worth considering when you use the words "crimes" or "criminal" whether those terms best express your meaning. Maybe they're still the words you want, but maybe sometimes there are more helpful ways to frame things.

In this report on #programming languages, we see that #Perl and #Haskell are now somewhat peers.

Their repo counts are both decline on Github, with Perl in decline about twice as fast.

The engagement metrics for #Rust in terms of "pushes per repository" and "forks per repository" are much higher than either.

#Python, coming of age in a similar era as Perl remains one of the most active languages on Github.

I credit Python's staying power to being easy to learn and straightforward.

Raven Luni @RavenLuni
home original

Balancing functionality and necessity: The biggest headache you will ever have in programming.

I use a VM-based compiler back end with its own pseudo-assembly language. For the latest version (Comp-Lex 2.0) I did the following:

Instead of traditional 'registers' I use variable declarations with:
- array indexing (immediate or variable based)
- arbritrary bit widths (non-byte aligned) (intended for ease of use with serial IO streams)
- associative arrays (needed for language identifiers)

The question is how much of that needed to be coded from scratch and how much could have been bootstrapped into a more elegant script using a simpler model (which will be done at some point anyway). Oh well too late now :p

#coding #compilers

home original

I've been following Tymoczko's work on math and music for a while. Lately I've been talking to him about some fancy math. Now I'll finally get to meet him and talk to him here in Edinburgh! Here's a less technical talk:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BCre43sfj9E

He's giving a talk tomorrow on Zoom, which you can watch:

Date: Wednesday November 21, 2025
Time: 13:00 IST
Location: Higgs Centre Seminar Room, Room 4305, JCMB
Speaker: Dmitri Tymoczko (Princeton University)
Title: Beyond the Geometry of Music

Abstract: People have been modeling music geometrically for more than 300 years. Early in the twenty first century it became clear that many existing models were orbifolds, quotients of Râ¿ (known to musicians as "n-note ordered pitch space") by various symmetry groups (e.g. the "OPTI" symmetries containing octave shifts, permutations, translations and reflections). Recently, however, it has become clear that some closely related musical models are not orbifolds, either because the parent space is inherently discrete or because the symmetry group does not act properly discontinuously. Music theorists thus need to be able to work with a wider range of quotients. My talk will survey some of the fascinating interactions between geometry and music, and will describe a new and more comprehensive framework using groupoids.

Online: https://ed-ac-uk.zoom.us/j/88480730026 Password: higgs_20

arclight @arclight
home original

Thanks to @timonsku for reminding me about my 2001 paper on computer system reliability modeling in the context of the recent internet outages https://www.usenix.org/legacy/publications/library/proceedings/lisa2001/tech/apthorpe/apthorpe.pdf

I don't know what's more depressing -- that I wrote this almost 25 years ago or that it's more relevant now than when it was published.

I can't complain it wasn't influential - I never tried building a career on it or did much self-promotion as a result. It needed a real application but PRA is expensive and at the time the main risk to internet infrastructure was bankruptcy as the bottom fell out of the dotcom industry.

Still, there are so many more critical dependencies, so much money and actual human lives at risk, you'd think well-funded companies like Cloudflare and Amazon would take risk management and assessment more seriously than is apparent. But safety is a cost and costs need to be shifted to the least able to afford them. Billionaires need their personal space programs after all.

How to turn of #AI in your #GMail account.

GMail -> Settings -> See all settings -> Scroll down to "Smart features" (see image below)

Turn off smart features (it will want to restart, you can do that), then go back there, go into the "Manage workspace smart feature settings" and turn the two options off

If you go back to "See all settings" you will find that a lot of sections are greyed out, because they are turned off.

home original

I really wish #Mastodon had a 'preview' feature for posts.

EDIT: Okay, apparently a lot of people don't understand what that means, so here goes:

Everywhere else I post on the Internet (and almost everywhere I have posted in the last 30 years) has a box I type in and then a preview button that shows me what the post will look like. Mastodon does not. I press the 'post button', then the 'open post' button, and then I get to see the final version. And then I discover rendering errors and have to go to edit to fix them. This is an awkward flow. A button that lets me preview the post and then post it once I'm happy with how it looks would be so much less annoying.

Minoru @minoru
home original
Thinking about LLMs as potentially useful tools (with many caveats)

I continue reading up on legal ramifications re LLMs.

https://matthewbutterick.com/chron/will-ai-obliterate-the-rule-of-law.html takes a rather philosophical angle compared to Mitchell's post. It's a generalisation of "copyright laundering" into "behaviour laundering". Current laws are written for humans and treat machines as instruments. These instruments can't be faulted; their operators take responsibility. However, if there appears a machine that can operate so autonomously that its agency gets on the level of humans, we got a problem: the machine can do whatever, and there is no legal recourse!

Butterick then goes on to analyse possible solutions. It feels to me that the history will end up creating it's own rather than pick from the list, but I can't pinpoint what exactly it might be.

#LargeLanguageModels #Law

@jackyan @Em0nM4stodon Dutch public Radio and TV did their research years ago, and found out that advertisements have *more* benefit (read: advertisers will pay more!) from being associated to the right content than from being associated to the profiles of the readers.

For example: advertise for hammers on a page about home improvement. It is likely that people visiting such a page are interested in hammers. Maybe even at that moment.

No profile needed.

A reminder: today is the Trans Day of Remembrance. For those unfamiliar, this is when we remember trans people who were killed by acts of violence.

On a day like this, and in the current broader crisis as well: it can be hard to remember that you are loved and to allow yourself to feel that love. Please take extra care of yourselves today.

Practicing both compassion for ourselves and compassion for each other is incredibly important in grief. Although many of us have lost people directly, there are also many who have not and who want to support those in their lives who have.

Here are a couple of resources that will hopefully help.

Self-compassion in grief:

https://www.apenneyforyourthoughts.com/mental-health-topics-1/self-compassionduringgriefandloss

Compassion for others in grief:

https://www.cedarcounselingandwellness.com/kindness-in-crisis/

**Edit** I wanted to add a more explicit request in here, rather than just leaving it to inference: please tell trans people in your life that you love and appreciate them every day but especially today.

#TransDayOfRemembrance

My hot take on Rust .unwrap(): no matter what you do, people want convenient shortcut ways of not explicitly handling errors in programming languages. And then people will use them in what turn out to be inappropriate places, because people aren't always right and sometimes make mistakes.

Every popular programming language lets your code not handle errors in some way, taking an optimistic approach. If you're lucky, your program notices at runtime when there actually is an error.

ğŸ’¬ 1 ğŸ” 6 â¤ï¸ 30 ğŸ¯ 0.05
FreeBSD Fortune @fbfortune ğŸ¤–
home original

You can install extra packages for FreeBSD by using the ports system.
If you have installed it, you can download, compile, and install software by
just typing

# cd /usr/ports/<category>/<portname>
# make install && make clean

as root. The ports infrastructure will download the software, change it so
it works on FreeBSD, compile it, install it, register the installation so it
will be possible to automatically uninstall it, and clean out the temporary
working space it used. You can remove an installed port you decide you do not
want after all by typing

# cd /usr/ports/<category>/<portname>
# make deinstall

as root.
